dublinCore.dc:title: 118 HR 6562 IH: Restore Everyone’s Sleep Tonight Act of 2023
dublinCore.dc:rights: Pursuant to Title 17 Section 105 of the United States Code, this file is not subject to copyright protection and is in the public domain.

action.action-desc: Mr. Panetta (for himself, Mr. Cárdenas, Ms. Eshoo, Mr. Mullin, and Mr. Sherman) introduced the following bill; which was referred to the Committee on Transportation and Infrastructure

form.official-title: To provide for a nighttime airport access restriction, and for other purposes.

section.text: This Act may be cited as the Restore Everyone’s Sleep Tonight Act of 2023 or the REST Act of 2023.

subsection.text: Notwithstanding any other provision of law and except as provided in subsection (b), an airport may impose an access restriction between the hours of 10 p.m. and 7 a.m. for aircrafts.

paragraph.text: In imposing an access restriction under subsection (a), an airport shall permit, within the hours of such access restriction, the operation of military, law enforcement, and Coast Guard flights.
In imposing an access restriction under subsection (a), an airport may not prohibit access for—

subparagraph.text: a flight that is scheduled to arrive or depart during hours not covered by the access restriction imposed under subsection (a) and which arrives or departs during such access restriction due solely to weather or the safe operation of the aircraft, including compliance with any safety-related requirements;
flights to evacuate natural disasters; and
flights for the purpose of the preservation of life, health, or safety.

paragraph.text: An airport may impose a noise deterrence penalty on an air carrier or aircraft operator for a violation of the access restriction imposed under subsection (a).

An airport applying penalties under this subsection shall set a base level for a noise deterrence penalty under paragraph (1) at an amount sufficient to deter future violations of the access restriction imposed under subsection (a).

The airport applying penalties under this subsection may increase a penalty for a violation of the access restriction imposed under subsection (a) above the base amount set under paragraph (2) if an aircraft takeoff or landing resulted in noise to residents of any unit of local government exceeding 80 dBA, as evidenced by a noise monitoring device recognized as authoritative by the airport.
In determining whether to increase the penalty above the base amount set under paragraph (2), an airport may consider the following:

subparagraph.text: The certified noise level and engine model of the aircraft.
Repeat violations by the air carrier or aircraft operator.
Any other criteria that the airport determines reflects the noise impacts to residents of the unit of local government impacted by the violation of subsection (a).

Except as provided in subparagraph (C), penalties collected for a violation of the access restriction imposed under subsection (a) shall be remitted to the unit of local government that experienced the impact of the noise deterrence violation.

If multiple units of local government are impacted by a violation of the access restriction imposed under subsection (a), an airport shall remit the penalty to the jurisdictions impacted in equal parts.
An airport may deduct reasonable costs of administering a noise deterrence penalty from a penalty collected under this paragraph before remitting the penalty under subparagraphs (A) and (B).

subsection.text: With respect to any action taken in carrying out this section, the airport is not required to seek the approval or comment of the Federal Aviation Administration or the Secretary of Transportation, any air carrier or aircraft operator or any other entity.
In this section, the term weather is defined as the state of the atmosphere at a location or along a route over the short-term.
For purposes of this Act, an access restriction is a prohibition on the landing or takeoff of aircraft.
